units.audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Math)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60 minutes: 10 warm-up, 15 mini-lesson, 20 guided practice, 10 independent, 5 exit ticket.

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Exponents & Radicals.
Solve multi-step problems involving Exponents & Radicals with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Exponents & Radicals and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 1.1 Laws of Exponents
objectives: Understand the purpose of 1.1 Laws of Exponents.
Practice representative problems for 1.1 Laws of Exponents.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 1.1 Laws of Exponents.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 1.1 Laws of Exponents: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
For a≠0 and integers m,n:

  1. am·an=am+n
  2. aman=am−n
  3. (am)n=amn
  4. (ab)m=ambm
  5. (ab)m=ambm
  6. a0=1
  7. a−m=1am

Examples
- x3·x5=x8
- y7y2=y5
- (2x)3=8x3
- x−4=1x4

structure.title: 1.2 Evaluating Expressions with Exponents
objectives: Understand the purpose of 1.2 Evaluating Expressions with Exponents.
Practice representative problems for 1.2 Evaluating Expressions with Exponents.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 1.2 Evaluating Expressions with Exponents.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 1.2 Evaluating Expressions with Exponents: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Substitute the value of the base and apply exponent rules.
  • Negative bases behave differently depending on exponent parity.

Examples
- 23=8
- (−2)4=16 (even power → positive)
- (−2)5=−32 (odd power → negative)
- 2−3=18

structure.title: 1.3 Solving Equations with Exponents
objectives: Understand the purpose of 1.3 Solving Equations with Exponents.
Practice representative problems for 1.3 Solving Equations with Exponents.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 1.3 Solving Equations with Exponents.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 1.3 Solving Equations with Exponents: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Case 1: Same base

Rewrite with the same base, then equate exponents.

Example

3x+1=35⇒x+1=5⇒x=4

Case 2: Different bases

Take logs when bases cannot be matched.

Example

2x=7⇒x=ln7ln2

structure.title: 1.4 Simplifying Square Roots
objectives: Understand the purpose of 1.4 Simplifying Square Roots.
Practice representative problems for 1.4 Simplifying Square Roots.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 1.4 Simplifying Square Roots.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 1.4 Simplifying Square Roots: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Key rules

  • ab=a·b
  • ab=ab,b>0
  • (a)2=a

Examples
- 50=25·2=52
- 728=728=9=3

Rationalizing the denominator

Multiply top and bottom by the radical to remove from denominator.

Example

32·22=322

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 1)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 1).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 1).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 1).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 1): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Simplify: x7y−3x−2y4
2) Evaluate: (−3)4 and −34 (note parentheses).
3) Solve for x: 52x−1=125
4) Simplify: 98
5) Rationalize: 75

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) x7−(−2)y−3−4=x9y−7=x9y7
2) (−3)4=81, but −34=−81
3) 125=53⇒2x−1=3⇒x=2
4) 98=49·2=72
5) 75·55=755

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Percent.
Solve multi-step problems involving Percent with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Percent and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 2.1 Definition of Percent
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.1 Definition of Percent.
Practice representative problems for 2.1 Definition of Percent.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.1 Definition of Percent.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.1 Definition of Percent: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A percent is a ratio out of 100.

Percent=PartWhole×100
  • 50% = 50100=12
  • 25% = 25100=14
  • 200% = 200100=2

structure.title: 2.2 Percent Change
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.2 Percent Change.
Practice representative problems for 2.2 Percent Change.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.2 Percent Change.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.2 Percent Change: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Formula

Percent Change=New−OriginalOriginal×100%
  • Positive → increase
  • Negative → decrease

Examples
1. Price from \40to\50:

50−4040×100=25% increase
  1. Price from \80to\60:
60−8080×100=−25% decrease

structure.title: 2.3 Simple Interest and Compound Interest
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.3 Simple Interest and Compound Interest.
Practice representative problems for 2.3 Simple Interest and Compound Interest.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.3 Simple Interest and Compound Interest.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.3 Simple Interest and Compound Interest: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Simple Interest

I=Prt
  • P = principal
  • r = rate (decimal)
  • t = time

Example: \1000at5I = 1000(0.05)(3)=150$

Compound Interest

A=P(1+rn)nt
  • A = total
  • P = principal
  • r = annual rate (decimal)
  • n = times compounded per year
  • t = time in years

Example: \$1000 at 5% compounded annually for 3 years

A=1000(1.05)3=1157.63

structure.title: 2.4 Percent Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.4 Percent Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 2.4 Percent Word Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.4 Percent Word Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.4 Percent Word Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 1
40% of students are girls. If there are 200 students, how many are girls?

0.40×200=80

Example 2
An item is discounted 20%, then taxed 5%. If original price is \$100:
- After discount: 100(0.8)=80
- After tax: 80(1.05)=84

structure.title: 2.5 Exponential vs. Linear Growth
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.5 Exponential vs. Linear Growth.
Practice representative problems for 2.5 Exponential vs. Linear Growth.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.5 Exponential vs. Linear Growth.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.5 Exponential vs. Linear Growth: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Linear growth: constant addition per step
    Example: salary increases \2000eachyear→y=2000t+P$
  • Exponential growth: constant multiplication per step
    Example: bacteria doubles every hour → y=P(2t)

structure.title: 2.6 Linear Growth and Decay
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.6 Linear Growth and Decay.
Practice representative problems for 2.6 Linear Growth and Decay.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.6 Linear Growth and Decay.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.6 Linear Growth and Decay: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Linear growth/decay equation:

y=y0+kt
  • k>0: growth
  • k<0: decay

Example
A tank loses 5 liters per hour, starting with 200:

y=200−5t

structure.title: 2.7 Exponential Growth and Decay
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.7 Exponential Growth and Decay.
Practice representative problems for 2.7 Exponential Growth and Decay.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.7 Exponential Growth and Decay.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.7 Exponential Growth and Decay: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
General formula:

y=y0(1±r)t
  • + for growth
  • − for decay

Example
Car worth \$20,000 depreciates 10% per year:

y=20000(0.9)t

structure.title: 2.8 Positive and Negative Association
objectives: Understand the purpose of 2.8 Positive and Negative Association.
Practice representative problems for 2.8 Positive and Negative Association.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 2.8 Positive and Negative Association.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 2.8 Positive and Negative Association: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Positive association: as x increases, y tends to increase.
  • Negative association: as x increases, y tends to decrease.

Examples - Hours studied vs. test score → positive
- Speed vs. travel time → negative

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 2)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 2).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 2).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 2).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 2): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Convert: (a) 0.2 to percent, (b) 150% to decimal.
2) Find percent change: 60 → 45.
3) Simple interest: \$800 at 6% for 2 years.
4) Compound interest: \$500 at 8% annually for 2 years.
5) Linear growth: population starts at 1000, grows by 50 per year. Write equation.
6) Exponential decay: medicine amount starts at 200 mg, halves each hour. Write equation.
7) Identify association:
- Number of hours worked vs. income.
- Hours of TV watched vs. GPA.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) (a) 0.2=20% (b) 150%=1.5
2) 45−6060×100=−25% (decrease)
3) I=800(0.06)(2)=96
4) A=500(1.08)2=583.20
5) y=1000+50t
6) y=200(0.5)t
7) Positive: hours worked vs. income. Negative: TV hours vs. GPA.

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Manipulating & Solving Equations.
Solve multi-step problems involving Manipulating & Solving Equations with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Manipulating & Solving Equations and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 3.1 Solving Linear Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.1 Solving Linear Equations.
Practice representative problems for 3.1 Solving Linear Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.1 Solving Linear Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.1 Solving Linear Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A linear equation has the general form:

ax+b=c

Steps:

  1. Move variable terms to one side.
  2. Move constants to the other.
  3. Divide by the coefficient of x.

Example

3x−5=16⇒3x=21⇒x=7

structure.title: 3.2 Equations with Variables on Both Sides
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.2 Equations with Variables on Both Sides.
Practice representative problems for 3.2 Equations with Variables on Both Sides.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.2 Equations with Variables on Both Sides.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.2 Equations with Variables on Both Sides: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example

5x+2=3x+8⇒5x−3x=8−2⇒2x=6⇒x=3

SAT Tip: Always combine like terms before solving.

structure.title: 3.3 Equations with Fractions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.3 Equations with Fractions.
Practice representative problems for 3.3 Equations with Fractions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.3 Equations with Fractions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.3 Equations with Fractions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example

x3+x6=5

Multiply through by the least common multiple (LCM) of the denominators:

6(x3+x6)=6(5)⇒2x+x=30⇒3x=30⇒x=10

structure.title: 3.4 Quadratic Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.4 Quadratic Equations.
Practice representative problems for 3.4 Quadratic Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.4 Quadratic Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.4 Quadratic Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A quadratic equation has the form:

ax2+bx+c=0

Methods:

  1. Factoring (when easy integers exist)
    Example:
x2+5x+6=0(x+2)(x+3)=0x=−2,x=−3
  1. Quadratic Formula
x=−b±b2−4ac2a
  1. Completing the Square
    Turn x2+bx into (x+b2)2 form.

structure.title: 3.5 Absolute Value Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.5 Absolute Value Equations.
Practice representative problems for 3.5 Absolute Value Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.5 Absolute Value Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.5 Absolute Value Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Definition:

|x|=k⇒x=k or x=−k

Example

|2x−3|=5⇒2x−3=5or2x−3=−5⇒x=4orx=−1

SAT Tip: Always check for extraneous solutions in absolute value and radical equations.

structure.title: 3.6 Radical Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.6 Radical Equations.
Practice representative problems for 3.6 Radical Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.6 Radical Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.6 Radical Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Equations with square roots:

Example

x+3=x−1
  1. Square both sides:
x+3=(x−1)2
  1. Expand:
x+3=x2−2x+1
  1. Rearrange:
0=x2−3x−2
  1. Factor:
(x−2)(x−(−1))=0x=2orx=−1
  1. Check: Plug into original equation - x=−1 gives 2=−2 (false), so only x=2 works.

structure.title: 3.7 Systems of Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 3.7 Systems of Equations.
Practice representative problems for 3.7 Systems of Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 3.7 Systems of Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 3.7 Systems of Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Two main methods on the SAT:

  1. Substitution - Solve one equation for one variable, substitute into the other.

  2. Elimination - Add/subtract equations to eliminate one variable.

Example

{x+y=102x−y=4

Add both:

3x=14 ⇒ x=143

Substitute into x+y=10:

143+y=10 ⇒ y=163

structure.title: Practice Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems.
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Solve: 7x−4=17
2) Solve: 2x+5=3x−7
3) Solve: x4−x6=5
4) Solve: x2−9x+20=0
5) Solve: |3x−4|=8
6) Solve:

{x−y=2x+y=8

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) 7x=21 ⇒ x=3
2) −x=−12 ⇒ x=12
3) LCM is 12: 3x−2x=60 ⇒ x=60
4) Factors of 20 that sum to -9: (-5, -4) → (x−5)(x−4)=0 → x=5, x=4
5) 3x−4=8 ⇒ x=4 or 3x−4=−8 ⇒ x=−43
6) Add: 2x=10 ⇒ x=5, then 5+y=8 ⇒ y=3

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Rates.
Solve multi-step problems involving Rates with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Rates and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 4.1 Definition
objectives: Understand the purpose of 4.1 Definition.
Practice representative problems for 4.1 Definition.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 4.1 Definition.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 4.1 Definition: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A rate compares two different quantities with different units.

Rate=Quantity AQuantity B

Examples - Speed = distancetime
- Density = massvolume
- Price per item = costnumber of items

structure.title: 4.2 Unit Rates
objectives: Understand the purpose of 4.2 Unit Rates.
Practice representative problems for 4.2 Unit Rates.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 4.2 Unit Rates.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 4.2 Unit Rates: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A unit rate expresses the rate per 1 unit.

Examples - 180 miles in 3 hours → 1803=60 miles/hour
- \12for4poundsofapples→\dfrac{12}{4} = 3$ dollars/pound

structure.title: 4.3 Conversion Factors
objectives: Understand the purpose of 4.3 Conversion Factors.
Practice representative problems for 4.3 Conversion Factors.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 4.3 Conversion Factors.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 4.3 Conversion Factors: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A conversion factor is a fraction equal to 1, used to change units.

Common examples - 1 hour=60 minutes
- 1 inch=2.54 cm
- 1 mile=5280 ft

Example
Convert 5 hours to minutes:

5 hr·60 min1 hr=300 min

structure.title: 4.4 Distance–Rate–Time Formula
objectives: Understand the purpose of 4.4 Distance–Rate–Time Formula.
Practice representative problems for 4.4 Distance–Rate–Time Formula.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 4.4 Distance–Rate–Time Formula.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 4.4 Distance–Rate–Time Formula: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Distance=Rate×Time
  • d=rt
  • r=dt
  • t=dr

Example
If speed is 50 mph for 3 hours:

d=50×3=150 miles

structure.title: 4.5 Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 4.5 Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 4.5 Word Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 4.5 Word Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 4.5 Word Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 1: Travel
A car travels 180 miles in 3 hours. What is its speed?

r=1803=60 mph

Example 2: Conversion
How many seconds in 2 hours?

2 hr·60 min1 hr·60 s1 min=7200 s

Example 3: Combined Rates
If Pipe A fills a tank in 4 hours, Pipe B fills the same tank in 6 hours, how long if both work together?
Rates: A=14, B=16. Combined = 14+16=512.
Time = 125=2.4 hours.

structure.title: 4.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 4.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 4.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 4.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 4.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always include units - many traps involve mismatched units.
  • For combined rates, add rates, not times.
  • For ratios in word problems, set up proportions.
  • Convert early to avoid mistakes (miles → feet, hours → minutes).

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 4)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 4).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 4).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 4).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 4): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) A runner covers 10 km in 50 minutes. What is her speed in km/h?
2) Convert 5 feet to inches.
3) A car travels 150 miles in 2.5 hours. Find speed in mph.
4) A faucet fills a tub in 15 minutes, another in 20 minutes. How long together?
5) A cyclist rides 12 miles in 40 minutes. Find unit rate in miles per hour.

Practice representative problems for Solutions.

structure.title: 5.1 Combining Like Terms

Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Like terms have the same variable raised to the same power.
  • Only their coefficients can be added or subtracted.

Examples - 3x+5x=8x
- 7y−2y=5y
- 2x2+3x−x2+4=(2x2−x2)+3x+4=x2+3x+4

structure.title: 5.2 Expansion and Factoring
objectives: Understand the purpose of 5.2 Expansion and Factoring.
Practice representative problems for 5.2 Expansion and Factoring.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 5.2 Expansion and Factoring.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 5.2 Expansion and Factoring: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Expansion

Use distributive property:

a(b+c)=ab+ac

Examples - (x+2)(x+3)=x2+5x+6
- (2x−5)(3x+4)=6x2−7x−20

Factoring

Reverse of expansion.
- Take out common factor.
- Use special patterns:

  1. Difference of squares:
a2−b2=(a−b)(a+b)
  1. Perfect square trinomials:
a2+2ab+b2=(a+b)2 a2−2ab+b2=(a−b)2

Examples - x2+7x+10=(x+5)(x+2)
- 9x2−25=(3x−5)(3x+5)

structure.title: 5.3 Combining, Dividing, and Splitting Fractions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 5.3 Combining, Dividing, and Splitting Fractions.
Practice representative problems for 5.3 Combining, Dividing, and Splitting Fractions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 5.3 Combining, Dividing, and Splitting Fractions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 5.3 Combining, Dividing, and Splitting Fractions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Adding/Subtracting

Must have common denominator.

ab+cd=ad+bcbd

Example

23+56=46+56=96=32

Multiplying

Multiply numerator and denominator directly.

ab·cd=acbd

Dividing

Multiply by reciprocal.

ab÷cd=ab·dc

Splitting Fractions

Distribute denominator:

a+bc=ac+bc

Example

x+63=x3+2

content.html:
• Always factor before canceling terms in fractions.
  • Look for special products: (a+b)2, (a−b)2, a2−b2.
  • Simplify step by step; avoid canceling across addition.
  • Expressions with radicals or fractions often simplify after factoring.

structure.title: 6.1 Common Mistakes to Avoid

lecture_script.script: Overview of 6.1 Common Mistakes to Avoid: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1. Cancelling incorrectly
    - Wrong: x+5x=1+5=6
    - Correct: x+5x=1+5x

  2. Losing solutions when multiplying/dividing by a variable
    - If you multiply or divide by x, always check x≠0.

  3. Forgetting to distribute negatives
    - −(x+3)=−x−3, not −x+3

  4. Square root mistake
    - x2=|x|, not x

lecture_script.script: Overview of 6.2 Tools for Isolating Variables: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Inverse operations

  • Addition ↔ Subtraction
  • Multiplication ↔ Division
  • Squaring ↔ Square root

Example
Solve 3x+7=16

3x=9⇒x=3

Balancing equations

What you do to one side, do to the other.

structure.title: 6.3 How to Deal with Complicated Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 6.3 How to Deal with Complicated Equations.
Practice representative problems for 6.3 How to Deal with Complicated Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 6.3 How to Deal with Complicated Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 6.3 How to Deal with Complicated Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Distribute and Combine

  • Expand parentheses and combine like terms.

Example
Solve 2(x+3)−(x−5)=12

2x+6−x+5=12⇒x+11=12⇒x=1

Fractions

  • Multiply through by least common denominator (LCD).

Example
Solve x3+25=1
Multiply both sides by 15:

5x+6=15⇒x=95

Decimals

  • Multiply through by powers of 10 to clear decimals.

Example
Solve 0.2x+0.5=1.3
Multiply through by 10:

2x+5=13⇒x=4

content.html:

  • Eliminate fractions and decimals early.
  • Plug solution back to check (some SAT questions have “extraneous solutions”).
  • Watch for absolute values, square roots, and restrictions.

structure.title: 7.1 Matching Coefficients
objectives: Understand the purpose of 7.1 Matching Coefficients.
Practice representative problems for 7.1 Matching Coefficients.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 7.1 Matching Coefficients.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 7.1 Matching Coefficients: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Useful when equations are polynomials or involve unknown coefficients.

Example 1
Suppose (ax+b)(x+2)=2x2+7x+6.
Expand LHS: ax2+(2a+b)x+2b.
Match coefficients with RHS:
- a=2
- 2a+b=7⇒4+b=7⇒b=3
- 2b=6 (checks out)

So a=2,b=3.

structure.title: 7.2 Clearing Denominators
objectives: Understand the purpose of 7.2 Clearing Denominators.
Practice representative problems for 7.2 Clearing Denominators.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 7.2 Clearing Denominators.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 7.2 Clearing Denominators: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
For equations with fractions, multiply both sides by the least common denominator (LCD).

Example 2
Solve x2+34=5.
LCD = 4. Multiply through:

2x+3=20⇒2x=17⇒x=172

Example 3
Solve 2x+3x+1=1.
LCD = x(x+1). Multiply through:

2(x+1)+3x=x(x+1) 2x+2+3x=x2+x⇒x2−4x−2=0

Solve quadratic:

x=4±16+82=4±242=2±6

structure.title: 7.3 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 7.3 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 7.3 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 7.3 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 7.3 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always check for restrictions when clearing denominators (denominators ≠0).
  • Matching coefficients often appears in SAT questions with polynomial identities.
  • After clearing denominators, check for extraneous solutions by plugging back.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Expand LHS: ax2+(a+b)x+b. Match with RHS 3x2+7x+2:
- a=3
- a+b=7⇒3+b=7⇒b=4
- b=2 conflict! → no solution.

2) Multiply through by 6: 2x+5=24⇒2x=19⇒x=192

3) LCD = x(x+2): (x+2)+x=34(x2+2x)
Simplify: 2x+2=34(x2+2x)
Multiply by 4: 8x+8=3x2+6x

3x2−2x−8=0

Solve: x=2±4+966=2±106
→ x=2 or x=−43

4) LCD = y(y+3): 2(y+3)−y=y(y+3)

2y+6−y=y2+3y

y+6=y2+3y y2+2y−6=0

Solve: y=−2±4+242=−2±282=−2±272
→ y=−1±7

structure.title: 8.1 Substitution
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.1 Substitution.
Practice representative problems for 8.1 Substitution.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.1 Substitution.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.1 Substitution: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Solve one equation for one variable, then substitute into the other.

Example 1
Solve:

y=2x+3 3x+y=12

Substitute y=2x+3:

3x+(2x+3)=12⇒5x+3=12⇒5x=9⇒x=95

.
Then y=2(95)+3=185+155=335.

Solution: (95,335).

structure.title: 8.2 Elimination
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.2 Elimination.
Practice representative problems for 8.2 Elimination.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.2 Elimination.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.2 Elimination: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Add or subtract equations to eliminate one variable.

Example 2
Solve:

2x+3y=12 4x−3y=6

Add equations: 6x=18⇒x=3.
Substitute: 2(3)+3y=12⇒6+3y=12⇒y=2.
Solution: (3,2).

structure.title: 8.3 Systems with No Solutions and Infinite Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.3 Systems with No Solutions and Infinite Solutions.
Practice representative problems for 8.3 Systems with No Solutions and Infinite Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.3 Systems with No Solutions and Infinite Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.3 Systems with No Solutions and Infinite Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• No solution (inconsistent): parallel lines with different intercepts.
    Example: y=2x+3, y=2x−4.

  • Infinite solutions (dependent): equations are multiples of each other.
    Example: 2x+4y=6, x+2y=3.

structure.title: 8.4 Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.4 Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 8.4 Word Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.4 Word Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.4 Word Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 3
A movie ticket costs \12foradultsand\8 for children. If 5 tickets cost \$52, how many adult and child tickets?

Let a = adults, c = children.

a+c=5 12a+8c=52

Multiply first eqn by 8: 8a+8c=40. Subtract from second: 4a=12⇒a=3.
Then c=2.

Solution: 3 adult, 2 child tickets.

structure.title: 8.5 More Complex Systems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.5 More Complex Systems.
Practice representative problems for 8.5 More Complex Systems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.5 More Complex Systems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.5 More Complex Systems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Sometimes 3 equations with 3 unknowns.

Example 4
Solve:

x+y+z=6 2x−y+z=4 x+2y−z=5

From first: z=6−x−y.
Substitute into second: 2x−y+(6−x−y)=4⇒x−2y+6=4⇒x−2y=−2⇒x=2y−2.

Sub into third: (2y−2)+2y−(6−(2y−2)−y)=5.
Simplify: 2y−2+2y−(6−2y+2−y)=5.

4y−2−(8−3y)=5

.

4y−2−8+3y=5⇒7y−10=5⇒7y=15⇒y=157

.

Then x=2(157)−2=307−147=167.

z=6−167−157=42−317=117

.

Solution: (167,157,117).

structure.title: 8.6 Graphs of Systems of Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.6 Graphs of Systems of Equations.
Practice representative problems for 8.6 Graphs of Systems of Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.6 Graphs of Systems of Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.6 Graphs of Systems of Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Each equation = line.
  • Solution = intersection point(s).
  • No intersection → no solution.
  • Same line → infinite solutions.

Example 5

y=2x+1

and y=−x+4

.
Graph: they intersect at (1,3).

structure.title: 8.7 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 8.7 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 8.7 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 8.7 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 8.7 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.

content.html:
• Always check the form: sometimes substitution is easier, sometimes elimination.
  • Be alert for “trick” systems (no solution or infinite).
  • Graphs can help visualize.
  • For word problems: define variables clearly, then set up equations.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 8)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 8).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 8).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 8): definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
1) Solve:

x+2y=7 3x−y=5

2) Solve:

2x+3y=10 4x+6y=12

3) Tickets to a play cost \5forstudentsand\12 for adults. If 10 tickets total \$81, how many of each type?

4) Solve:

x+y=4 x−y=2

5) Solve the 3-variable system:

x+2y+z=9 2x−y+z=4 x−y+2z=8

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) From first: x=7−2y. Substitute: 3(7−2y)−y=5⇒21−6y−y=5⇒−7y=−16⇒y=167. Then x=7−327=177. Solution: (177,167).

2) Second eqn is multiple of first but different constant → no solution.

3) s+a=10, 5s+12a=81. Multiply first by 5: 5s+5a=50. Subtract: 7a=31⇒a=317 (not integer). On SAT, maybe trick - check wording.

4) Add equations: 2x=6⇒x=3. Then 3+y=4⇒y=1. Solution: (3,1).

5) From first: x=9−2y−z. Substitute into second: 2(9−2y−z)−y+z=4⇒18−4y−2z−y+z=4⇒−5y−z=−14⇒5y+z=14. Call this (A).
Also substitute into third: (9−2y−z)−y+2z=8⇒9−3y+z=8⇒−3y+z=−1⇒3y−z=1. Call this (B).
Add (A)+(B): 8y=15⇒y=158. Then 3(158)−z=1⇒458−z=1⇒z=378. Then x=9−2(158)−378=72−30−378=58.
Solution: (58,158,378).

structure.title: 9.1 How to Solve Inequalities
objectives: Understand the purpose of 9.1 How to Solve Inequalities.
Practice representative problems for 9.1 How to Solve Inequalities.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 9.1 How to Solve Inequalities.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 9.1 How to Solve Inequalities: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Rules are similar to solving equations, with one key difference:
- When multiplying or dividing both sides by a negative number, the inequality sign flips.

Example 1
Solve: 3x−7<11

3x<18⇒x<6

Example 2
Solve: −2x+5≥9

−2x≥4⇒x≤−2

structure.title: 9.2 Inequality Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 9.2 Inequality Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 9.2 Inequality Word Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 9.2 Inequality Word Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 9.2 Inequality Word Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Translate carefully from words to math.

Example 3
A concert ticket costs \40.Youhaveatmost\250. How many tickets can you buy?

40x≤250⇒x≤6.25

So maximum whole tickets = 6.

Example 4
A test requires at least 70 points to pass. You currently have 42 points out of 60. How many of the remaining 40 points must you get?

Let x = points you score on last part.

42+x≥70⇒x≥28

So you must earn at least 28 points.

structure.title: 9.3 Graphs of Inequalities
objectives: Understand the purpose of 9.3 Graphs of Inequalities.
Practice representative problems for 9.3 Graphs of Inequalities.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 9.3 Graphs of Inequalities.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 9.3 Graphs of Inequalities: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• For one-variable inequalities:
  • x<3 → open circle at 3, shade left.

  • x≥−2 → closed circle at -2, shade right.

  • For two-variable inequalities:

  • Example: y≤2x+1 → graph line y=2x+1. Shade below because of ≤.
  • Use dashed line for < or >; solid line for ≤ or ≥.

Example 5
Graph solution set of:

y>−x+2

Line: y=−x+2, slope −1, intercept 2. Dashed line. Shade region above.

structure.title: 9.4 Systems of Inequalities
objectives: Understand the purpose of 9.4 Systems of Inequalities.
Practice representative problems for 9.4 Systems of Inequalities.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 9.4 Systems of Inequalities.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 9.4 Systems of Inequalities: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
The solution is the overlap region of all shaded areas.

Example 6
Graph and solve:

y≥x+1 y<−2x+4

The solution region is the intersection of the two shaded half-planes.

structure.title: 9.5 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 9.5 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 9.5 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 9.5 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 9.5 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always flip the inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative.
  • Check boundary points (does equality hold?).
  • For word problems, highlight key phrases like “at most,” “at least,” “no more than.”
  • Graph shading is common on SAT - test with a sample point like (0,0).

One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Solve: 5x+2>17
2) Solve: −3x+7≤1
3) A taxi charges \4perrideplus\2 per mile. You have at most \$30. How many miles can you ride?
4) Solve and graph: y≤12x+3
5) System of inequalities:

y>2x−1,y≤−x+4

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
1) 5x+2>17⇒5x>15⇒x>3.

2) −3x+7≤1⇒−3x≤−6⇒x≥2.

3) Cost equation: 4+2m≤30⇒2m≤26⇒m≤13. So up to 13 miles.

4) Line: y=12x+3, slope 12, intercept 3. Solid line (since ≤). Shade below.

5) Graph both: y>2x−1 (above dashed line), y≤−x+4 (below solid line). Solution = overlap region.

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Word Problems.
Solve multi-step problems involving Word Problems with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Word Problems and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 10.1 Basic Setup Examples
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.1 Basic Setup Examples.
Practice representative problems for 10.1 Basic Setup Examples.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.1 Basic Setup Examples.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.1 Basic Setup Examples: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 1
A number increased by 7 is 20. Find the number.

Let x = the number.

x+7=20⇒x=13

structure.title: 10.2 Geometry Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.2 Geometry Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 10.2 Geometry Word Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.2 Geometry Word Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.2 Geometry Word Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 2
A rectangle has length 3 more than twice its width. If the perimeter is 42, find dimensions.

Let width = w, length = 2w+3.

2w+2(2w+3)=42⇒2w+4w+6=42⇒6w=36⇒w=6

Then l=2(6)+3=15.
Rectangle: 6×15.

structure.title: 10.3 Motion Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.3 Motion Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 10.3 Motion Word Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.3 Motion Word Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.3 Motion Word Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Distance = rate × time.

Example 3
A car travels 60 miles in the same time a train travels 100 miles. If the train is twice as fast, find car’s speed.

Let r = car speed. Train speed = 2r.
Time = distance/rate.

60r=1002r⇒60r=50r

Contradiction → no solution. Check: maybe train is not exactly twice but “20 mph faster.”

Revised Problem
Car: r, Train: r+20, Times equal.

60r=100r+20

Cross-multiply: 60(r+20)=100r⇒60r+1200=100r⇒40r=1200⇒r=30.
Car = 30 mph, Train = 50 mph.

structure.title: 10.4 Work Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.4 Work Problems.
Practice representative problems for 10.4 Work Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.4 Work Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.4 Work Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Work rate = 1 / (time to finish).

Example 4
Alice can paint a room in 4 hours, Bob in 6 hours. How long together?

Rates: Alice = 1/4, Bob = 1/6. Together = 1/4+1/6=5/12.
So time = 1/(5/12)=12/5=2.4 hours.

structure.title: 10.5 Mixture Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.5 Mixture Problems.
Practice representative problems for 10.5 Mixture Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.5 Mixture Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.5 Mixture Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 5
A 20-liter solution is 25% acid. How much water to add to make it 10% acid?

Acid = 0.25(20)=5 liters.
Final solution: 20+x liters, still 5 acid.

520+x=0.10⇒5=0.1(20+x)⇒5=2+0.1x⇒0.1x=3⇒x=30

Add 30 liters water.

structure.title: 10.6 Consecutive Integer Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.6 Consecutive Integer Problems.
Practice representative problems for 10.6 Consecutive Integer Problems.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.6 Consecutive Integer Problems.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.6 Consecutive Integer Problems: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 6
Find three consecutive integers whose sum is 96.

Let numbers = n,n+1,n+2.

n+(n+1)+(n+2)=96⇒3n+3=96⇒3n=93⇒n=31

Numbers: 31, 32, 33.

structure.title: 10.7 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 10.7 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 10.7 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 10.7 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 10.7 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Define variables before writing equations.
  • Watch out for “at least,” “at most” (inequalities).
  • Always answer in the context of the problem (no raw variables).
  • Plug answer choices back in if stuck (backsolving).

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 10)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 10).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 10).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 10).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 10): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) A number decreased by 8 is 15. What is the number?
2) A rectangle has width w and length 3w. If area = 75, find w.
3) A plane flies 600 miles in the same time a car drives 200 miles. If plane speed is 4 times car speed, find speeds.
4) Two workers can finish a job in 5 hours together. If one works twice as fast as the other, how long alone for each?
5) A 40-liter mixture is 30% sugar. How much pure sugar to add to make it 50% sugar?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) x−8=15⇒x=23.

2) w(3w)=75⇒3w2=75⇒w2=25⇒w=5.

3) Car = r, Plane = 4r. 600/(4r)=200/r⇒150/r=200/r. Contradiction → recheck wording. Likely: “Plane is 300 mph faster.”
Try: 600/(r+300)=200/r. Cross multiply: 600r=200(r+300)⇒600r=200r+60,000⇒400r=60,000⇒r=150. Car = 150 mph, Plane = 450 mph.

4) Let slow = r, fast = 2r. Together rate = 3r. Time = 1/(3r)=5⇒3r=1/5⇒r=1/15. So slow = 15 hrs, fast = 7.5 hrs.

5) Sugar initially = 0.3(40)=12. Add x sugar → total sugar = 12+x, total volume = 40+x.
Equation: (12+x)/(40+x)=0.5⇒12+x=0.5(40+x)=20+0.5x.

0.5x−x=12−20=−8⇒−0.5x=−8⇒x=16

.
Add 16 liters sugar.

structure.title: 11.1 Slope and y-Intercept
objectives: Understand the purpose of 11.1 Slope and y-Intercept.
Practice representative problems for 11.1 Slope and y-Intercept.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 11.1 Slope and y-Intercept.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 11.1 Slope and y-Intercept: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Slope (m): measures steepness.
m=riserun=y2−y1x2−x1
  • y-intercept (b): point where line crosses y-axis.

Equation form:

y=mx+b

Example 1
Find slope and intercept of line through (2,3) and (4,7).

m=7−34−2=42=2

Equation: y=2x+b. Plug (2,3): 3=2(2)+b⇒3=4+b⇒b=−1.
Final: y=2x−1.

structure.title: 11.2 Equations of Lines
objectives: Understand the purpose of 11.2 Equations of Lines.
Practice representative problems for 11.2 Equations of Lines.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 11.2 Equations of Lines.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 11.2 Equations of Lines: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Slope-Intercept Form

y=mx+b

Point-Slope Form

y−y1=m(x−x1)

Example 2
Equation of line through (1,2) with slope −3:

y−2=−3(x−1)⇒y=−3x+5

structure.title: 11.3 Finding the Intersection of Two Lines
objectives: Understand the purpose of 11.3 Finding the Intersection of Two Lines.
Practice representative problems for 11.3 Finding the Intersection of Two Lines.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 11.3 Finding the Intersection of Two Lines.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 11.3 Finding the Intersection of Two Lines: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Solve system of equations.

Example 3
Find intersection of y=2x+1 and y=−x+4.

Set equal:

2x+1=−x+4⇒3x=3⇒x=1

Then y=2(1)+1=3.
Intersection = (1,3).

structure.title: 11.4 Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
objectives: Understand the purpose of 11.4 Parallel and Perpendicular Lines.
Practice representative problems for 11.4 Parallel and Perpendicular Lines.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 11.4 Parallel and Perpendicular Lines.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 11.4 Parallel and Perpendicular Lines: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Parallel lines: same slope, different intercepts.
  • Perpendicular lines: slopes multiply to −1 (negative reciprocals).

Example 4
Find equation of line parallel to y=3x+2 through (0,5).

Slope = 3. Equation: y=3x+5.

Example 5
Find equation of line perpendicular to y=12x−1 through (2,0).

Slope = −1(12)=−2.
Equation: y−0=−2(x−2)⇒y=−2x+4.

structure.title: 11.5 Horizontal and Vertical Lines
objectives: Understand the purpose of 11.5 Horizontal and Vertical Lines.
Practice representative problems for 11.5 Horizontal and Vertical Lines.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 11.5 Horizontal and Vertical Lines.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 11.5 Horizontal and Vertical Lines: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Horizontal: y=c (slope = 0).
  • Vertical: x=c (slope undefined).

Example 6
Equation of line through (3,−2) and parallel to y=−2:
Answer: y=−2.

Example 7
Equation of line through (4,5) and parallel to x=1:
Answer: x=4.

structure.title: 11.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 11.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 11.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 11.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 11.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Memorize slope formulas.
  • Parallel → same m.
  • Perpendicular → m1·m2=−1.
  • Watch out for vertical/horizontal lines.
  • For intersections, substitution is often faster than graphing.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 11)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 11).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 11).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 11).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 11): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Find slope and intercept of line through (0,4) and (2,10).
2) Write equation of line with slope 5 through (1,−3).
3) Find intersection of y=3x+1 and y=−2x+6.
4) Write equation of line parallel to y=−4x+7 through (2,1).
5) Write equation of line perpendicular to y=2x−5 through (−1,2).

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) m=(10−4)/(2−0)=6/2=3. Equation: y=3x+4.

2) Point-slope: y+3=5(x−1)⇒y=5x−8.

3) 3x+1=−2x+6⇒5x=5⇒x=1,y=4. Intersection (1,4).

4) Parallel slope −4. Equation: y−1=−4(x−2)⇒y=−4x+9.

5) Perpendicular slope −12. Equation: y−2=−12(x+1)⇒y=−12x+32.

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Interpreting Linear Models.
Solve multi-step problems involving Interpreting Linear Models with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Interpreting Linear Models and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 12.1 Meaning of the Slope
objectives: Understand the purpose of 12.1 Meaning of the Slope.
Practice representative problems for 12.1 Meaning of the Slope.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 12.1 Meaning of the Slope.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 12.1 Meaning of the Slope: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Slope is the change in y per unit change in x.
  • Interpreted as a rate.

Example 1
A taxi company charges according to the equation:

Cost=2.5x+4

where x = miles traveled.

  • Slope = 2.5 → cost increases by \$2.50 per mile.
  • Intercept = 4 → flat starting fee = \$4.

structure.title: 12.2 Meaning of the Intercept
objectives: Understand the purpose of 12.2 Meaning of the Intercept.
Practice representative problems for 12.2 Meaning of the Intercept.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 12.2 Meaning of the Intercept.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 12.2 Meaning of the Intercept: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Intercept is the value of y when x=0.
  • Often represents initial condition.

Example 2
Temperature T=70−2t, where t = hours after noon.

  • Intercept = 70 → temperature at noon = 70°F.
  • Slope = -2 → temperature drops 2°F each hour.

structure.title: 12.3 Predictions with Linear Models
objectives: Understand the purpose of 12.3 Predictions with Linear Models.
Practice representative problems for 12.3 Predictions with Linear Models.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 12.3 Predictions with Linear Models.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 12.3 Predictions with Linear Models: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
You can use the equation to predict values.

Example 3
A company’s revenue is modeled by:

R=5000+200t

where t = months.

  • After 6 months:
R=5000+200(6)=6200

So revenue = \$6200.

structure.title: 12.4 Limitations of Models
objectives: Understand the purpose of 12.4 Limitations of Models.
Practice representative problems for 12.4 Limitations of Models.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 12.4 Limitations of Models.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 12.4 Limitations of Models: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Models may not apply for all x.
  • Negative values may be meaningless (e.g., negative time, negative price).
  • Always check context.

Example 4
If h=100−5t gives height of rocket (t= seconds), then at t=30:

h=100−150=−50

Negative height is meaningless → model only valid for small t.

structure.title: 12.5 Scatterplots & Line of Best Fit
objectives: Understand the purpose of 12.5 Scatterplots & Line of Best Fit.
Practice representative problems for 12.5 Scatterplots & Line of Best Fit.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 12.5 Scatterplots & Line of Best Fit.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 12.5 Scatterplots & Line of Best Fit: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
On the SAT:
- A line of best fit is given.
- You may be asked to interpret slope/intercept.
- Or check if a point fits the model.

Example 5
Scatterplot shows relation between study hours (x) and test score (y). Line of best fit:

y=50+5x
  • Intercept = 50 → baseline score with 0 study = 50.
  • Slope = 5 → each study hour adds 5 points.

structure.title: 12.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 12.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 12.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 12.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 12.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Identify units for slope/intercept.
  • Watch for unrealistic predictions.
  • If a graph/table is shown, pick two points to compute slope.
  • Double-check whether the model describes growth or decline.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 12)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 12).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 12).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 12).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 12): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) A cell phone plan costs C=40+0.1m, where m = number of minutes. Interpret slope and intercept.

2) A car’s value is modeled as V=20,000−1200y, where y = years since purchase. What does slope mean?

3) A fitness app predicts weight loss with W=180−2t, where t = weeks. Find weight after 5 weeks.

4) The line of best fit for data is y=30+4x. Interpret slope in context.

5) A model predicts y=100−15x. For x=10, what is y? Is this prediction reasonable?

objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.

content.html:
1) Intercept = 40 → fixed monthly fee \40.Slope=0.1→eachminuteadds\0.10.

2) Slope = -1200 → car loses \$1200 value each year.

3) W=180−2(5)=170. After 5 weeks, weight = 170 lbs.

4) Slope = 4 → each increase of 1 unit in x raises y by 4.

5) y=100−15(10)=100−150=−50. Prediction meaningless (negative). Model not valid for large x.

structure.title: 13.1 What is a Function?
objectives: Understand the purpose of 13.1 What is a Function?.
Practice representative problems for 13.1 What is a Function?.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 13.1 What is a Function?.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 13.1 What is a Function?: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Each x has only one y.
  • You cannot have two outputs for the same input.

Example 1
Is this a function?
- (1,2),(2,3),(3,4) → Yes (every input unique).
- (1,2),(1,3),(2,4) → No (input 1 has two outputs).

structure.title: 13.2 When is a Function Undefined?
objectives: Understand the purpose of 13.2 When is a Function Undefined?.
Practice representative problems for 13.2 When is a Function Undefined?.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 13.2 When is a Function Undefined?.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 13.2 When is a Function Undefined?: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Division by zero is not allowed.
  • Square roots of negatives are not real.
  • Logarithms of nonpositive numbers are undefined.

Example 2

f(x)=1x−3

is undefined at x=3

.

Example 3

g(x)=x−5

is undefined if x<5

.

structure.title: 13.3 Composite Functions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 13.3 Composite Functions.
Practice representative problems for 13.3 Composite Functions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 13.3 Composite Functions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 13.3 Composite Functions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
If f(x) and g(x) are functions, then:

(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))

Example 4
If f(x)=2x+1 and g(x)=x2, find (f∘g)(3).

(f∘g)(3)=f(g(3))=f(9)=2(9)+1=19

structure.title: 13.4 Finding the Solutions to a Function
objectives: Understand the purpose of 13.4 Finding the Solutions to a Function.

content.html:
Solve f(x)=k for x.

Example 5
If f(x)=x2−4, solve f(x)=5.

x2−4=5⇒x2=9⇒x=±3

structure.title: 13.5 Identifying Function Graphs
objectives: Understand the purpose of 13.5 Identifying Function Graphs.

content.html:
• Vertical Line Test: If a vertical line crosses graph more than once → not a function.

Example 6
- y=x2 → function (parabola passes test).
- Circle x2+y2=1 → not a function (fails vertical line test).

content.html:
• Watch for undefined values.
  • Composition is a common SAT trick.
  • Always check if graphs pass vertical line test.
  • Solutions to f(x)=k mean x-values where graph crosses y=k.

content.html:
1) Is y=x a function? Why or why not?
2) For h(x)=5x+2, where is it undefined?
3) If f(x)=3x−4 and g(x)=x2+1, find (g∘f)(2).
4) Solve f(x)=x2+2x when f(x)=8.
5) Does the graph of a sideways parabola x=y2 represent a function?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Yes, y=x is a function since each input has only one output (though domain is x≥0).

2) Denominator =0 at x=−2, so undefined there.

3) (g∘f)(2)=g(f(2))=g(2)=(22+1)=5 where f(2)=3(2)−4=2. So g(2)=5.

4) x2+2x=8⇒x2+2x−8=0⇒(x+4)(x−2)=0⇒x=−4,2.

5) No, x=y2 fails vertical line test (two y for each x>0).

structure.title: 14.1 Tactics for Finding the Roots
objectives: Understand the purpose of 14.1 Tactics for Finding the Roots.
Practice representative problems for 14.1 Tactics for Finding the Roots.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 14.1 Tactics for Finding the Roots.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 14.1 Tactics for Finding the Roots: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
The roots/solutions of a quadratic are the x-values where y=0.
Methods:

  1. Factoring
    Example: x2−5x+6=0
(x−2)(x−3)=0⇒x=2,3
  1. Quadratic Formula
    For ax2+bx+c=0:
x=−b±b2−4ac2a
  1. Completing the Square (see below).

structure.title: 14.2 Completing the Square
objectives: Understand the purpose of 14.2 Completing the Square.
Practice representative problems for 14.2 Completing the Square.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 14.2 Completing the Square.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 14.2 Completing the Square: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Transform quadratic into vertex form.

Example 1
Solve x2+6x+5=0 by completing the square.

x2+6x+5=(x2+6x+9)−9+5=(x+3)2−4

Set =0:

(x+3)2=4⇒x=−3±2

So x=−1,−5.

structure.title: 14.3 The Vertex and Vertex Form
objectives: Understand the purpose of 14.3 The Vertex and Vertex Form.
Practice representative problems for 14.3 The Vertex and Vertex Form.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 14.3 The Vertex and Vertex Form.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 14.3 The Vertex and Vertex Form: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A parabola’s vertex is given by:

x=−b2a,y=f(−b2a)

Vertex form:

y=a(x−h)2+k

where (h,k) = vertex.

Example 2

y=x2−4x+1

Vertex: x=42=2.

y=(2)2−4(2)+1=4−8+1=−3

.
Vertex = (2,−3).

structure.title: 14.4 The Discriminant
objectives: Understand the purpose of 14.4 The Discriminant.
Practice representative problems for 14.4 The Discriminant.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 14.4 The Discriminant.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 14.4 The Discriminant: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
The discriminant is inside quadratic formula:

Δ=b2−4ac
  • Δ>0 → 2 real roots
  • Δ=0 → 1 real root (double root)
  • Δ<0 → no real roots (complex roots)

Example 3

x2+2x+5=0

, Δ=22−4(1)(5)=4−20=−16<0

→ no real solutions.

structure.title: 14.5 Quadratic Models
objectives: Understand the purpose of 14.5 Quadratic Models.
Practice representative problems for 14.5 Quadratic Models.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 14.5 Quadratic Models.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 14.5 Quadratic Models: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Quadratics model motion, area, profit, etc.

Example 4
Height of ball: h=−16t2+32t+48 (feet).
- Vertex gives maximum height.

t=−b2a=−322(−16)=1

.

h=−16(1)2+32(1)+48=64

.
Max height = 64 ft at t=1 sec.

structure.title: 14.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 14.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 14.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 14.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 14.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always check if factoring is quick.
  • Memorize quadratic formula.
  • Discriminant saves time for “how many solutions” questions.
  • Parabolas open upward if a>0, downward if a<0.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Factor: (x−3)(x−4)=0⇒x=3,4.

2) a=2,b=3,c=−5:

x=−3±32−4(2)(−5)2(2)=−3±494 x=−3±74⇒x=1,−52

3) x=−42=−2, y=(−2)2+4(−2)−1=4−8−1=−5. Vertex (−2,−5).

4) Δ=62−4(1)(10)=36−40=−4<0 → no real roots.

5) Vertex: t=−202(−5)=2.

h=−5(2)2+20(2)+30=−20+40+30=50

.
Max height = 50.
