structure.title: 15.1 Performing Synthetic Division
objectives: Understand the purpose of 15.1 Performing Synthetic Division.
Practice representative problems for 15.1 Performing Synthetic Division.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 15.1 Performing Synthetic Division.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 15.1 Performing Synthetic Division: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Steps: 1. Write down coefficients of dividend (fill in 0 for missing terms).
2. Write c from (x−c).
3. Bring down the first coefficient.
4. Multiply by c, add to next coefficient, repeat.

Example 1
Divide 2x3+3x2−5x+6 by x−2.

Set up:

223−564141827924

Quotient: 2x2+7x+9, remainder 24.
So:

2x3+3x2−5x+6x−2=2x2+7x+9+24x−2

structure.title: 15.2 Equivalent Expressions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 15.2 Equivalent Expressions.
Practice representative problems for 15.2 Equivalent Expressions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 15.2 Equivalent Expressions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 15.2 Equivalent Expressions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
If remainder = 0, the divisor is a factor.

Example 2
Divide x3−6x2+11x−6 by x−1.

Set up:

11−611−61−561−560

Quotient: x2−5x+6, remainder 0.
So (x−1) is a factor.

structure.title: 15.3 The Remainder Theorem
objectives: Understand the purpose of 15.3 The Remainder Theorem.
Practice representative problems for 15.3 The Remainder Theorem.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 15.3 The Remainder Theorem.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 15.3 The Remainder Theorem: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
For f(x) divided by (x−c), the remainder is simply f(c).

Example 3

f(x)=x3+2x2−3x+1

. Find remainder when divided by x−2

.

Compute f(2)=23+2(22)−3(2)+1=8+8−6+1=11.
So remainder = 11.

structure.title: 15.4 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 15.4 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 15.4 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 15.4 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 15.4 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Use remainder theorem to save time.
  • If f(c)=0, then (x−c) is a factor.
  • Synthetic division only works for divisors of form (x−c), not x2+...

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 15)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 15).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 15).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 15): definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
1) Divide x3+4x2−7x+2 by x−3.
2) Divide 2x3−9x2+7x+6 by x−2.
3) Use the remainder theorem: find remainder of f(x)=x4−5x3+2 when divided by x+1.
4) Factor x3−4x2+x+6 completely using synthetic division.
5) If f(x)=2x3+5x2−3x+1, is (x−1) a factor?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1)

314−7232142171444

Quotient: x2+7x+14, remainder 44.

2)

22−9764−10−62−5−30

Quotient: 2x2−5x−3, remainder 0.

3) f(−1)=(−1)4−5(−1)3+2=1+5+2=8. Remainder = 8.

4) Test factors: f(2)=0. Divide by (x−2).

21−4162−4−61−2−30

Quotient: x2−2x−3=(x−3)(x+1).
So x3−4x2+x+6=(x−2)(x−3)(x+1).

5) f(1)=2(1)3+5(1)2−3(1)+1=2+5−3+1=5≠0.
So (x−1) is not a factor.

structure.title: 17.1 Basic Properties
objectives: Understand the purpose of 17.1 Basic Properties.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 17.1 Basic Properties: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1. |a|≥0 (always nonnegative).
  2. |−a|=|a|.
  3. |ab|=|a||b|.
  4. |ab|=|a||b|,b≠0.
  5. Triangle inequality: |a+b|≤|a|+|b|.

structure.title: 17.2 Solving Absolute Value Equations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 17.2 Solving Absolute Value Equations.
Practice representative problems for 17.2 Solving Absolute Value Equations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 17.2 Solving Absolute Value Equations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 17.2 Solving Absolute Value Equations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Case 1: |x|=a

  • If a≥0: x=a or x=−a.
  • If a<0: No solution.

Example 1
Solve |x|=7.

x=7orx=−7

Case 2: |x+b|=c

Split into two cases.

Example 2
Solve |x−3|=5.

x−3=5⇒x=8 x−3=−5⇒x=−2

structure.title: 17.3 Solving Absolute Value Inequalities
objectives: Understand the purpose of 17.3 Solving Absolute Value Inequalities.
Practice representative problems for 17.3 Solving Absolute Value Inequalities.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 17.3 Solving Absolute Value Inequalities.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 17.3 Solving Absolute Value Inequalities: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1. |x|<a⇒−a<x<a
  2. |x|≤a⇒−a≤x≤a
  3. |x|>a⇒x<−a or x>a

Example 3
Solve |x−4|<3.

−3<x−4<3⇒1<x<7

Example 4
Solve |2x+1|≥5.

2x+1≥5⇒x≥2 2x+1≤−5⇒x≤−3

structure.title: 17.4 Absolute Value in Word Problems
objectives: Understand the purpose of 17.4 Absolute Value in Word Problems.
Practice representative problems for 17.4 Absolute Value in Word Problems.

content.html:
Distance is always nonnegative.

Example 5
A number is within 4 units of 10. Find the range of possible values.

Equation: |x−10|≤4.

6≤x≤14

structure.title: 18.1 Exterior Angle Theorem
objectives: Understand the purpose of 18.1 Exterior Angle Theorem.
Practice representative problems for 18.1 Exterior Angle Theorem.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 18.1 Exterior Angle Theorem.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 18.1 Exterior Angle Theorem: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
In a triangle, the exterior angle is equal to the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.

Exterior Angle=Remote Interior Angle 1+Remote Interior Angle 2

Example 1
In a triangle, one exterior angle is 120∘. If one remote interior angle is 40∘, the other is:

120∘−40∘=80∘

structure.title: 18.2 Parallel Lines and Angles
objectives: Understand the purpose of 18.2 Parallel Lines and Angles.
Practice representative problems for 18.2 Parallel Lines and Angles.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 18.2 Parallel Lines and Angles.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 18.2 Parallel Lines and Angles: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
When a transversal cuts two parallel lines:

  • Corresponding angles are equal.
  • Alternate interior angles are equal.
  • Same-side interior angles are supplementary.

Example 2
If one angle is 70∘, then the corresponding angle is also 70∘.

structure.title: 18.3 Polygons
objectives: Understand the purpose of 18.3 Polygons.
Practice representative problems for 18.3 Polygons.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 18.3 Polygons.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 18.3 Polygons: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Interior Angle Sum

For an n-sided polygon:

Sum of interior angles=(n−2)×180∘

Each Interior Angle (regular polygon)

(n−2)×180∘n

Each Exterior Angle (regular polygon)

360∘n

Example 3
A hexagon (n=6):
- Interior angle sum =(6−2)×180=720∘
- Each interior angle =720/6=120∘

structure.title: 18.4 Angle Pairs
objectives: Understand the purpose of 18.4 Angle Pairs.
Practice representative problems for 18.4 Angle Pairs.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 18.4 Angle Pairs.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 18.4 Angle Pairs: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Complementary angles: sum =90∘
  • Supplementary angles: sum =180∘
  • Vertical angles: equal

Example 4
If two supplementary angles are in ratio 2:7, find them.

2x+7x=180⇒9x=180⇒x=20

Angles = 40∘,140∘

structure.title: 18.5 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 18.5 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 18.5 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 18.5 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 18.5 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always check for parallel lines → look for equal angles.
  • For polygons, memorize (n−2)×180∘.
  • Exterior angle theorem is very common.
  • Watch out for “trick” wording with supplements/complements.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 18)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 18).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 18).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 18).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 18): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) In a triangle, one angle is 50∘ and another is 60∘. Find the exterior angle adjacent to the third angle.
2) Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. If one angle is 75∘, find its alternate interior angle.
3) Find the sum of interior angles of a decagon.
4) Find each interior angle of a regular octagon.
5) Two angles are complementary. One is x, the other is 2x. Solve for x.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Third angle =180−50−60=70∘. Exterior angle = 180−70=110∘.

2) Alternate interior angle = 75∘.

3) (10−2)×180=8×180=1440∘.

4) (8−2)×180/8=6×180/8=108∘.

5) x+2x=90⇒3x=90⇒x=30.

content.html:
• Isosceles Triangle: 2 equal sides → 2 equal angles.
  • Equilateral Triangle: All sides equal, all angles =60∘.

Example 1
If an isosceles triangle has vertex angle 40∘, each base angle is:

180−402=70∘

structure.title: 19.2 Right Triangles
objectives: Understand the purpose of 19.2 Right Triangles.
Practice representative problems for 19.2 Right Triangles.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 19.2 Right Triangles.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 19.2 Right Triangles: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A right triangle has one 90∘ angle.
Pythagorean theorem:

a2+b2=c2

where c is the hypotenuse.

Common triples: (3,4,5), (5,12,13), (7,24,25), (8,15,17).

structure.title: 19.3 Special Right Triangles
objectives: Understand the purpose of 19.3 Special Right Triangles.
Practice representative problems for 19.3 Special Right Triangles.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 19.3 Special Right Triangles.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 19.3 Special Right Triangles: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
45-45-90 Triangle

  • Legs equal.
  • Hypotenuse =leg·2.

30-60-90 Triangle

  • Short leg =x.
  • Hypotenuse =2x.
  • Long leg =x3.

Example 2
In a 30-60-90 triangle, if the hypotenuse is 10, then:
- Short leg =5
- Long leg =53

structure.title: 19.4 Similar Triangles
objectives: Understand the purpose of 19.4 Similar Triangles.
Practice representative problems for 19.4 Similar Triangles.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 19.4 Similar Triangles.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 19.4 Similar Triangles: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Triangles are similar if their angles are equal and sides proportional.

a1a2=b1b2=c1c2

Example 3
If △ABC~△DEF, and AB=4, BC=6, EF=9, find DE.

Scale factor =69=23.
So DE=AB·32=4·32=6.

structure.title: 19.5 Radians
objectives: Understand the purpose of 19.5 Radians.
Practice representative problems for 19.5 Radians.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 19.5 Radians.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 19.5 Radians: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Radians measure angles in terms of arc length.

180∘=π radians

Conversions:
- Degrees → radians: multiply by π/180
- Radians → degrees: multiply by 180/π

Example 4
Convert 120∘ to radians:

120∘·π180=2π3

structure.title: 19.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 19.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 19.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 19.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 19.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always check if triangle is special (30-60-90 or 45-45-90).
  • Use Pythagorean triples to save time.
  • Mark equal sides/angles in isosceles problems.
  • Watch for hidden similar triangles (especially in geometry diagrams).

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 19)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 19).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 19).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 19).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 19): definitions, properties, and key formulas.

One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Find the missing angle in a triangle with angles 40∘ and 75∘.
2) In an isosceles triangle, the vertex angle is 100∘. Find the base angles.
3) A right triangle has legs 9 and 12. Find the hypotenuse.
4) In a 45-45-90 triangle, the hypotenuse is 8. Find the legs.
5) Convert 225∘ into radians.
6) Two similar triangles have sides 3,4,5 and 6,x,10. Find x.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) 180−40−75=65∘.

2) Base angles =(180−100)/2=40∘.

3) c=92+122=81+144=225=15.

4) Leg =8/2=42.

5) 225∘·π/180=5π4.

6) Scale factor =2. So x=8.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 20.1 Area and Circumference: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Circumference:
C=2πr=πd
  • Area:
A=πr2

Example 1
If r=7, then:

C=14π,A=49π

structure.title: 20.2 Arc Length
objectives: Understand the purpose of 20.2 Arc Length.
Practice representative problems for 20.2 Arc Length.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 20.2 Arc Length.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 20.2 Arc Length: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Arc length is a portion of the circumference:

s=θ360∘·2πr

(or s=θr if θ in radians).

Example 2
Find the arc length of a 90∘ arc in a circle of radius 4.

s=90360·2π(4)=2π

structure.title: 20.3 Area of a Sector
objectives: Understand the purpose of 20.3 Area of a Sector.
Practice representative problems for 20.3 Area of a Sector.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 20.3 Area of a Sector.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 20.3 Area of a Sector: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Sector area is a portion of the total area:

Asector=θ360∘·πr2

(or Asector=12r2θ if θ in radians).

Example 3
Find the area of a 60∘ sector with r=6:

A=60360·π(36)=6π

structure.title: 20.4 Central and Inscribed Angles
objectives: Understand the purpose of 20.4 Central and Inscribed Angles.
Practice representative problems for 20.4 Central and Inscribed Angles.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 20.4 Central and Inscribed Angles.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 20.4 Central and Inscribed Angles: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Central angle: vertex at the circle’s center, equals arc measure.
  • Inscribed angle: vertex on the circle, equals half the arc it intercepts.

Example 4
If arc AB=80∘, then:
- Central angle =80∘
- Inscribed angle =40∘

structure.title: 20.5 Equations of Circles
objectives: Understand the purpose of 20.5 Equations of Circles.
Practice representative problems for 20.5 Equations of Circles.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 20.5 Equations of Circles.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 20.5 Equations of Circles: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
General form:

(x−h)2+(y−k)2=r2

where (h,k) is the center and r the radius.

Example 5
Equation of circle centered at (3,−2) with r=5:

(x−3)2+(y+2)2=25

structure.title: 20.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 20.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 20.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 20.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 20.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.

content.html:
• Inscribed angle = half arc is very common.
  • For arc/sector problems, always check if θ is in degrees or radians.
  • If you see x2+y2 terms, think “equation of a circle.”
  • Don’t forget diameter =2r when needed.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 20)

Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 20).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 20): definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
1) Find the circumference of a circle with r=10.
2) Find the area of a circle with diameter 12.
3) In a circle of radius 5, find the length of an arc subtended by 72∘.
4) Find the area of a 90∘ sector with r=8.
5) In a circle, arc AB=100∘. Find the inscribed angle subtending that arc.
6) Write the equation of a circle centered at (2,3) with radius 7.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
1) C=2π(10)=20π.

2) r=6⇒A=π(36)=36π.

3) s=72360·2π(5)=2π.

4) A=90360·π(64)=16π.

5) Inscribed angle =100/2=50∘.

6) (x−2)2+(y−3)2=49.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 21.1 Sine, Cosine, and Tangent: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
In a right triangle:

sinθ=oppositehypotenuse,cosθ=adjacenthypotenuse,tanθ=oppositeadjacent

Example 1
In a right triangle, opposite =3, adjacent =4, hypotenuse =5:

sinθ=35,cosθ=45,tanθ=34

structure.title: 21.2 Trigonometric Identities
objectives: Understand the purpose of 21.2 Trigonometric Identities.
Practice representative problems for 21.2 Trigonometric Identities.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 21.2 Trigonometric Identities.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 21.2 Trigonometric Identities: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Pythagorean Identity

sin2θ+cos2θ=1

Tangent Identity

tanθ=sinθcosθ,cosθ≠0

Example 2
If sinθ=513, find cosθ.

cosθ=1−sin2θ=1−25169=1213

structure.title: 21.3 Evaluating Trigonometric Expressions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 21.3 Evaluating Trigonometric Expressions.

content.html:
• Use special right triangles (30-60-90, 45-45-90).
  • Know common values:
sin30∘=12,cos30∘=32,tan30∘=13 sin45∘=22,cos45∘=22,tan45∘=1 sin60∘=32,cos60∘=12,tan60∘=3

Example 3
Evaluate tan45∘:

tan45∘=1

structure.title: 21.4 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 21.4 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 21.4 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 21.4 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:

  • Memorize exact values for 30∘,45∘,60∘.
  • Use sin2+cos2=1 to find missing values.
  • Watch for trick questions mixing degrees and radians.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 21)

content.html:
1) In a right triangle, opposite =8, hypotenuse =17. Find sinθ and cosθ.
2) If cosθ=1213, find sinθ.
3) Evaluate sin30∘+cos60∘.
4) Find tanθ if sinθ=513 and cosθ=1213.
5) Simplify sin245∘+cos245∘.

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Adjacent =172−82=289−64=225=15.

sinθ=817,cosθ=1517

2) sinθ=1−cos2θ=1−144169=513.

3) sin30∘=12, cos60∘=12 → sum =1.

4) tanθ=sinθcosθ=5/1312/13=512.

5) sin245∘+cos245∘=1.

structure.title: 22.1 Types of Data Representations
objectives: Understand the purpose of 22.1 Types of Data Representations.
Practice representative problems for 22.1 Types of Data Representations.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 22.1 Types of Data Representations.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 22.1 Types of Data Representations: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Tables: Organize data into rows and columns.
  • Bar Graphs: Compare discrete categories.
  • Line Graphs: Show trends over time.
  • Pie Charts: Show proportions of a whole.
  • Scatterplots: Show relationships between two variables.

structure.title: 22.2 Common Skills
objectives: Understand the purpose of 22.2 Common Skills.
Practice representative problems for 22.2 Common Skills.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 22.2 Common Skills.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 22.2 Common Skills: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Finding Totals

Add values across rows or columns.

Example 1
A table shows that 20 boys and 15 girls joined the math club.

Total=20+15=35

Percentages

Convert part-to-whole into percent.

Example 2
In a survey, 30 students like soccer, 10 like basketball.

Soccer percent=3040×100=75%

Ratios

Express comparisons in simplest form.

Example 3
If a pie chart shows 120 students: 90 prefer cats, 30 prefer dogs.

Ratio cats:dogs=9030=3:1

Interpreting Trends

Look at increases/decreases in line graphs.

  • Rising line → positive trend.
  • Falling line → negative trend.
  • Flat line → no change.

structure.title: 22.3 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 22.3 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 22.3 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 22.3 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 22.3 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.

content.html:
• Read axes carefully (units often trick students).
  • Watch for scales not starting at 0.
  • Double-check if a question asks for percent vs. raw number.
  • Ratios are part-to-part, percents are part-to-whole.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 22)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 22).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 22).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 22).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 22): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) A bar graph shows sales: Monday 40, Tuesday 60, Wednesday 50.
- What is the average daily sales?

2) A pie chart shows 200 students: 50 like math, 75 like science, rest like history.
- What percent like history?

3) A line graph shows company revenue: Year 1 = 100k, Year 2 = 120k, Year 3 = 90k.
- What is the overall percent change from Year 1 to Year 3?

4) A scatterplot shows a positive association.
- What does this mean about the two variables?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Average = (40+60+50)/3=150/3=50.

2) History =200−(50+75)=75.

75200×100=37.5%

3) Change =90k−100k=−10k.

−10k100k×100=−10%

4) As one variable increases, the other tends to increase.

structure.title: 23.1 Basic Probability
objectives: Understand the purpose of 23.1 Basic Probability.
Practice representative problems for 23.1 Basic Probability.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 23.1 Basic Probability.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 23.1 Basic Probability: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
P(E)=Number of favorable outcomesTotal outcomes
  • 0≤P(E)≤1
  • P(certain event)=1
  • P(impossible event)=0

Example 1
A fair die is rolled. What is P(rolling a 4)?

P=16

structure.title: 23.2 Complementary Probability
objectives: Understand the purpose of 23.2 Complementary Probability.
Practice representative problems for 23.2 Complementary Probability.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 23.2 Complementary Probability.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 23.2 Complementary Probability: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
P(not E)=1−P(E)

Example 2
Probability of rolling a 6 on a die is 16.
Probability of not rolling a 6 is:

1−16=56

structure.title: 23.3 Independent Events
objectives: Understand the purpose of 23.3 Independent Events.
Practice representative problems for 23.3 Independent Events.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 23.3 Independent Events.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 23.3 Independent Events: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Events are independent if outcome of one does not affect the other.

P(A and B)=P(A)·P(B)

Example 3
Flip a coin and roll a die.

P(Heads and a 3)=12·16=112

structure.title: 23.4 Mutually Exclusive Events
objectives: Understand the purpose of 23.4 Mutually Exclusive Events.
Practice representative problems for 23.4 Mutually Exclusive Events.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 23.4 Mutually Exclusive Events.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 23.4 Mutually Exclusive Events: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Events that cannot both occur.

P(A or B)=P(A)+P(B)

Example 4
Pick a card from a deck. P(Ace or King):

452+452=852=213

structure.title: 23.5 Probability with Counting
objectives: Understand the purpose of 23.5 Probability with Counting.
Practice representative problems for 23.5 Probability with Counting.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 23.5 Probability with Counting.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 23.5 Probability with Counting: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Use combinations or listing.

Example 5
From 5 students (A,B,C,D,E), 1 is chosen at random.
Probability it’s A or B:

25

structure.title: 23.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 23.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 23.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 23.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 23.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Decide if events are independent or mutually exclusive.
  • Watch for “at least one” → use complement rule.
  • In card/dice questions, always confirm total outcomes.
  • Reduce fractions!

content.html:
1) A fair coin is flipped. Find P(Heads).
2) A bag has 3 red, 2 blue marbles. Pick one at random. P(Blue)?
3) Roll two dice. What’s P(sum = 7)?
4) A card is drawn from a deck. Find P(spade or heart).
5) What is the probability of not rolling a 5 on a fair die?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.

content.html:
1) P=12.

2) P=25.

3) Favorable outcomes: (1,6),(2,5),(3,4),(4,3),(5,2),(6,1) → 6 total.
Total outcomes = 36.

P=636=16

4) Spades = 13, Hearts = 13.

P=2652=12

5) 1−16=56.

structure.title: 24.1 Mean, Median, and Mode
objectives: Understand the purpose of 24.1 Mean, Median, and Mode.
Practice representative problems for 24.1 Mean, Median, and Mode.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 24.1 Mean, Median, and Mode.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 24.1 Mean, Median, and Mode: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Mean (average):
Mean=Sum of valuesNumber of values
  • Median: Middle value when data is ordered.

  • If even number of values → average the two middle numbers.

  • Mode: The most frequent value.

Example 1
Data: [2,3,3,4,5]
- Mean =(2+3+3+4+5)/5=17/5=3.4
- Median =3
- Mode =3

structure.title: 24.2 Range and Standard Deviation
objectives: Understand the purpose of 24.2 Range and Standard Deviation.
Practice representative problems for 24.2 Range and Standard Deviation.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 24.2 Range and Standard Deviation.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 24.2 Range and Standard Deviation: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Range:
Range=Max−Min
  • Standard Deviation (SD):
    A measure of how spread out data is.
    Larger SD → more spread.
    Smaller SD → values closer to the mean.

Example 2
Set A: [10,10,10,10] → SD = 0 (no spread).
Set B: [5,10,15] → larger spread, larger SD.

structure.title: 24.3 Histograms and Dot Plots
objectives: Understand the purpose of 24.3 Histograms and Dot Plots.
Practice representative problems for 24.3 Histograms and Dot Plots.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 24.3 Histograms and Dot Plots.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 24.3 Histograms and Dot Plots: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Histogram: Shows frequency of values in intervals (bins).
  • Dot Plot: Uses dots above a number line to show frequency.

SAT often asks:
- Which interval is most common?
- Approximate median/mean from the graph.

structure.title: 24.4 Word Problems Involving Averages
objectives: Understand the purpose of 24.4 Word Problems Involving Averages.
Practice representative problems for 24.4 Word Problems Involving Averages.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 24.4 Word Problems Involving Averages.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 24.4 Word Problems Involving Averages: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Example 3
The average of 4 test scores is 80. If three of them are 85, 75, 90, find the missing score.

85+75+90+x4=80⇒250+x=320⇒x=70

structure.title: 24.5 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 24.5 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 24.5 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 24.5 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 24.5 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always sort data before finding the median.
  • If one value is much larger/smaller → mean shifts, median less affected.
  • SD questions are usually relative (“which set has greater spread?”).
  • Carefully read graph axes.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 24)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 24).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 24).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 24).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 24): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Find the mean of [4,6,8,10].
2) Data: [2,5,7,8,12]. What is the median?
3) What is the mode of [1,2,2,3,4,4,4,5]?
4) Find the range of [9,14,22,5,17].
5) A histogram shows most students scored between 70–80. What does this tell you about the mode?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Mean =(4+6+8+10)/4=28/4=7.

2) Ordered set [2,5,7,8,12] → median =7.

3) Mode =4 (appears 3 times).

4) Range =22−5=17.

5) The mode is in the 70–80 interval.

learning_objectives: Define and apply key properties related to Statistics II.
Solve multi-step problems involving Statistics II with algebraic reasoning.
Model word problems about Statistics II and interpret solutions with correct units.

structure.title: 25.1 Statistical Sampling
objectives: Understand the purpose of 25.1 Statistical Sampling.
Practice representative problems for 25.1 Statistical Sampling.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 25.1 Statistical Sampling.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 25.1 Statistical Sampling: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Random Sample: Every member has equal chance of being selected → most reliable.
  • Biased Sample: Favors certain members → unreliable.

Example
Surveying only basketball players to estimate average student height = biased.
Surveying random students across school = better.

structure.title: 25.2 Using and Interpreting the Line of Best Fit
objectives: Understand the purpose of 25.2 Using and Interpreting the Line of Best Fit.
Practice representative problems for 25.2 Using and Interpreting the Line of Best Fit.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 25.2 Using and Interpreting the Line of Best Fit.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 25.2 Using and Interpreting the Line of Best Fit: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Scatterplots often include a regression line.

  • Positive slope: As x increases, y tends to increase.
  • Negative slope: As x increases, y tends to decrease.
  • Closer points to line: Stronger correlation.

Example
If best-fit line is y^=2x+5, then for x=4:

y^=2(4)+5=13

structure.title: 25.3 Margin of Error
objectives: Understand the purpose of 25.3 Margin of Error.
Practice representative problems for 25.3 Margin of Error.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 25.3 Margin of Error.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 25.3 Margin of Error: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Every estimate from a sample has some uncertainty.

  • Smaller sample size → larger margin of error.
  • Larger sample size → smaller margin of error.

Example
Poll shows 60% ± 3%. True population proportion is likely between 57% and 63%.

structure.title: 25.4 Confidence Intervals
objectives: Understand the purpose of 25.4 Confidence Intervals.
Practice representative problems for 25.4 Confidence Intervals.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 25.4 Confidence Intervals.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 25.4 Confidence Intervals: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
A confidence interval provides a range that likely contains the true population value.

  • A 95% confidence interval means if the survey were repeated many times, 95% of the intervals would contain the true value.

Example
A survey estimates average GPA = 3.2 with 95% CI (3.0,3.4).
Interpretation: The true GPA is likely between 3.0 and 3.4.

structure.title: 25.5 Experimental Design and Conclusions
objectives: Understand the purpose of 25.5 Experimental Design and Conclusions.
Practice representative problems for 25.5 Experimental Design and Conclusions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 25.5 Experimental Design and Conclusions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 25.5 Experimental Design and Conclusions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Correlation does not imply causation!
  • Randomized controlled experiments are most reliable.
  • Observational studies can show association but not cause.

Example
Data shows students who eat breakfast score higher.
Conclusion: Eating breakfast is associated with higher scores, but may not be the cause (other factors like sleep could matter).

structure.title: 25.6 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 25.6 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 25.6 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 25.6 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 25.6 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Look for wording like biased, random, representative.
  • Be careful: SAT may trick with causation vs. correlation.
  • For line of best fit → always use the equation given, not your own guess.
  • Interpret margin of error and confidence intervals correctly.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 25)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 25).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 25).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 25).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 25): definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) A school surveys only students in the honor society to estimate average study time. Is this sample biased?

2) A scatterplot shows a strong negative correlation. What does this mean?

3) A poll shows 48% support ± 4%. What is the interval of possible true support?

4) A best-fit line is y^=−3x+20. Predict y^ when x=5.

5) Researchers observe that students who text more tend to sleep less. Can they conclude texting causes less sleep?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Yes - it’s biased, since only honor students are surveyed.

2) As x increases, y tends to decrease.

3) Interval = (44%,52%).

4) y^=−3(5)+20=−15+20=5.

5) No - it only shows correlation, not causation.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 26.1 Volume of Prisms and Cylinders: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
• Prism (rectangular box, etc.):
V=Base Area×Height
  • Cylinder:
V=πr2h

Example 1
A cylinder has radius 3 and height 10.

V=π(32)(10)=90π

structure.title: 26.2 Volume of Pyramids and Cones
objectives: Understand the purpose of 26.2 Volume of Pyramids and Cones.
Practice representative problems for 26.2 Volume of Pyramids and Cones.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 26.2 Volume of Pyramids and Cones: definitions, properties, and key formulas.

content.html:
• Pyramid:
V=13(Base Area)(Height)
  • Cone:
V=13πr2h

Example 2
A cone with radius 4 and height 9:

V=13π(42)(9)=48π

structure.title: 26.3 Volume of a Sphere
objectives: Understand the purpose of 26.3 Volume of a Sphere.
Practice representative problems for 26.3 Volume of a Sphere.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 26.3 Volume of a Sphere.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 26.3 Volume of a Sphere: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.

content.html:
V=43πr3

Example 3
A sphere with radius 5:

V=43π(53)=5003π

structure.title: 26.4 Composite Solids
objectives: Understand the purpose of 26.4 Composite Solids.
Practice representative problems for 26.4 Composite Solids.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 26.4 Composite Solids.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 26.4 Composite Solids: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
Sometimes shapes are combined or parts are removed.
Strategy: Add or subtract volumes.

Example 4
A cylinder with r=3,h=10 is filled with a cone (r=3,h=10).
Volume difference = πr2h−13πr2h=23πr2h

=23π(9)(10)=60π

structure.title: 26.5 SAT Tips
objectives: Understand the purpose of 26.5 SAT Tips.
Practice representative problems for 26.5 SAT Tips.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in 26.5 SAT Tips.

lecture_script.script: Overview of 26.5 SAT Tips: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
• Always confirm if radius or diameter is given.
  • Watch units! SAT may ask in cubic centimeters, etc.
  • If asked about volume change, compare ratios instead of recalculating everything.
  • Example: If radius doubles, sphere’s volume increases by factor 23=8.

structure.title: Practice Problems (Unit 26)
objectives: Understand the purpose of Practice Problems (Unit 26).
Practice representative problems for Practice Problems (Unit 26).
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Practice Problems (Unit 26).

lecture_script.script: Overview of Practice Problems (Unit 26): definitions, properties, and key formulas.

One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) Find the volume of a rectangular box with dimensions 4×5×6.

2) A sphere has radius 7. Find its volume.

3) A cone has diameter 10 and height 12. Find its volume.

4) A cylinder has radius 5 and height 20. Find its volume.

5) If the radius of a sphere doubles, by what factor does its volume increase?

structure.title: Solutions
objectives: Understand the purpose of Solutions.
Practice representative problems for Solutions.
Avoid common mistakes commonly seen in Solutions.

lecture_script.script: Overview of Solutions: definitions, properties, and key formulas.
Model a typical SAT item: annotate givens, plan solution, compute, and check reasonableness.
Solve 2–3 scaffolded examples; students justify each step and units.
One short problem; show work, then thumbs check for confidence.

content.html:
1) V=4×5×6=120.

2) V=43π(73)=13723π.

3) Radius = 5.

V=13π(52)(12)=100π

4) V=π(52)(20)=500π.

5) Volume increases by 23=8 times.
